text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This section discusses the overall management of the transportation program for the IRS.

1.22.6.10.2, Prevention of Loss and Damage, section has been removed. The GSA handbook referenced is no longer available and there is no replacement. Previous section 1.22.6.10.3, Tracing Lost Shipment or Verifying Delivery, was renumbered to 1.22.6.10.2.
Editorial changes have been made throughout the IRM.

Purpose: This section discusses the IRS transportation management program.
The IRS Transportation Management Program provides guidelines and proce- dures for shipments required in managing IRS programs.
The IRS regularly ships items using several modes of transportation, including:
Negotiating rates and providing carrier service options to all IRS business
1.22 Mail and Transportation Management
Monitoring and controlling Forms
, Internal Revenue Service Lading (IRBL) and
, Internal Revenue Service Bill of Lading- Privately Owned Personal Property Reviewing carrier or vendor invoices Reviewing SF

, Public Voucher for Transportation Charges, forwards it Government Payables and Funds Management (GPFM) payment Acting in an advisory capacity to all business units Issuing IRBLs to provide transportation services to M&P and units Servicewide Assuring adequate funding is properly approved
The Pre-Payment Auditor receives the invoices from the moving companies and reviews the invoices for accuracy and appropriateness of rates.
PTP program manager approves users for the Transportation Management Program (TMS) used for creating Internal Revenue Bills of Lading (IRBLs).

Terms Term Deﬁnition Internal Revenue Service Tender of Service (IRSTOS) Provides the terms for freight carriers to submit their freight costs. Traffic Management System (TMS) TMS is the program to create IRBLs, maintain the freight carrier information and rates, and maintain addresses. Internal Revenue Bill of Lading (IRBL) Authorizes the Carrier to coordi- nate and transport the shipments.

CFR
(I), Transportation Service Provider (TSP) Performance (

) The PTP section provides a quality control program to monitor carrier perfor- mance, retains the high quality service providers with the best value and removes carriers with low quality service or excess cost. (
CFR

(I) allows IRS to place carriers in a temporary non-use status when evidence of deﬁciencies exist, such as: a. Late pickups or deliveries, or inconsistent transit times b. Freight bills with loss, damage, or other discrepancies c. Frequent overcharges or incomplete invoices (
) If the PTP section determines a carrier disciplinary action is necessary, IRS offices are notiﬁed. Transportation (

) The PTP section annually reviews the transportation management program these areas: • Current Fiscal Year (FY) budget • Internal Revenue Bills of Lading (IRBLs) • Claims • Tenders of Solicitation • Budget for upcoming FY • Program improvements (
) An Annual TM report providing the information on the above areas is provided to Chief, PTP no later than October
th for the preceding ﬁscal year. (
) The Annual TM report is provided to Chief, DRB no later than November for the preceding ﬁscal year. (
) CARE will receive the Annual TM report no later than December
st for the preceding ﬁscal year. Lading (

) The IRS (PTP, FMSS, Information Technology (IT) or GPFM) initiates freight Household Goods (HHG) transportation by issuing the Internal Revenue Service Bill of Lading (IRBL). The IRBL is a contract which speciﬁes the terms and conditions of carriage, the IRS rate authority and any special services. (
) The IRBL shows the description of the shipment and lists origin(s) and destina- tion(s).

IRS (PTP, FMSS, Information Technology (IT) or GPFM) initiates freight or Household Goods (HHG) transportation by issuing the Internal Revenue Service Bill of Lading (IRBL). The IRBL is a contract which speciﬁes the terms conditions of carriage, the IRS rate authority and any special services.
The IRBL shows the description of the shipment and lists origin(s) and destina-
) The IRS uses the IRBL for moving HHG and freight shipments, generally
pounds. Smaller shipments are handled by a Small Package Carrier (SPC) or the United States Postal Service (USPS) who do not accept the IRBL. (
) For IRS shipping, the IRBL has replaced the Government Bill of Lading (GBL). IRBLs (
) There are two types of IRBLs: a. Form
, Internal Revenue Service Bill of Lading, used for freight shipments and issued by authorized IRS users primarily in PTP, FMSS and IT. b. Form

, Internal Revenue Bill of Lading-Privately Owned Personal Property, used for shipments of HHG and personal effects of relocating employees. This IRBL is issued by the GPFM, Administrative Accounting Branch, Travel Management Section . (
) The purpose of the IRBL is to initiate and control individual freight or HHG shipments and to facilitate payment to the carrier. (
) The IRBL is only used for transportation of property when charges are to be paid by the IRS direct to the carrier. (

) An IRBL can be issued after the transportation services are completed: a. To replace or convert a Commercial Bill of Lading (CBL) b. To authorize payment for accessorial services billed separately (
) A duplicate IRBL may be issued if the original is lost or destroyed but not for separate shipments. (
) Any IRS office requesting an IRBL for a freight shipment must complete Form
, Freight Services Request, and submit by e-mail to wi.mp.traffic. management@irs.gov . a Bill of (CBL) to an Revenue Service Lading (IRBL) (

) When unable to create an IRBL, IRS offices are authorized to substitute a to originate a shipment when: a. The IRS Transportation Management System (TMS) is not accessible b. No authorized TMS user is on duty c. A PTP section employee is unavailable for assistance d. Emergency circumstances exist (
) When using this option, the carrier must be told no IRBL is available for the driver. The carrier can offer to prepare a CBL. (

) If the carrier does not offer to provide a CBL, the IRS shipping office can access the carrier web site and prepare the CBL online. A generic CBL can downloaded from the web, or a blank CBL can be obtained from the carrier driver for manual preparation. (
) For the carrier to receive payment for the CBL(s), the IRS shipping office issue an IRBL to the carrier converting the CBL to an IRBL. Transportation Management

, Internal Revenue Service Bill of Lading, used for freight shipments and issued by authorized IRS users primarily in PTP, FMSS and IT. b. Form

For the carrier to receive payment for the CBL(s), the IRS shipping office must issue an IRBL to the carrier converting the CBL to an IRBL.
) or Correcting of Lading (
) Form
, IRS US Government Bill of Lading Correction Notice, is required when making changes after an IRBL is issued to the carrier. The preparer Form
must ensure funds are available to cover any additional costs. copy of the completed form is maintained by the preparer, sent to the IRBL issuing office and the GPFM.
) and Accountability of Revenue Service of Lading (IRBLs) Government Bills of (GBLs) (

) An IRBL can only be issued by an authorized user on the TMS. To obtain thorization, employees must submit a request using the Business Entitlement Access Request System (BEARS). Once approved, employees will receive user identiﬁcation and password from a PTP section employee. (

) The paper GBL is replaced by the IRBL for IRS shipping. Any paper GBLs on hand should be shredded. For accountability purposes the numbers of GBLs being destroyed must be listed and retained in the ﬁle with a copy scanned and securely emailed to: wi.mp.traffic.management@irs.gov.
) Freight shipments funded by Distribution must be shipped on an IRBL, showing the authorized appropriation codes. (
) Freight shipments funded by other business units must show the Procurement for Public Sector (PPS) number and corresponding appropriation codes on IRBL. (
) Business units must request funding in PPS to generate the appropriation codes.
) Accounting and for Transportation (
) M&P/Distribution, in conjunction with GPFM is responsible for the proper mitment and obligation of funds for payment of transportation charges. (
) M&P is responsible for payment of the transportation charges on freight shipments made using an IRS SPC account (typically under

pounds per destination) or with an IRBL when the following conditions apply: a. From printers on Free on Board (FOB) Origin, FOB Contractor City and Government Printing Office (GPO) contracts to destinations designated by the IRS b. Between the IRS offices on printed product transfers directed by M&P c. From the IRS offices on SPC or truck shipments of administrative ﬁles, tax records or Grand Jury records requiring secure transportation to an IRS storage facility or Federal Records Center; shipment must be pallet- ized and shrink wrapped, and ready for pickup. d. Any shipment authorized by the PTP section (
) Requesting office/Business office is responsible for payment of transportation charges on freight shipments under the Home as POD (H
) and the IRS Telework programs. (

) Carriers will submit all public vouchers to the designated prepayment audit contractor as shown on the IRBL. After veriﬁcation of charges by the contrac- tor, the vouchers will be forwarded to the PTP section, certiﬁed for payment the PTP section and forwarded to GPFM for payment in compliance with the Prompt Payment Act.

Transportation (
) The IRS uses three primary modes of transportation, SPC (express and ground), motor freight (truckload (TL) and less-than-truckload (LTL)) and air freight. (
) The mode of transportation is determined by the lowest cost for the customer’s requirements. Routing (

) Two important steps in traffic management is negotiation of pricing and routing. a. Pricing is the cost of transportation services expressed by a rate, based on units of weight or distance. The PTP section negotiates rates with various carriers to satisfy the transportation needs of the entire IRS. b. Routing is choosing the best mode of transportation and selecting the best value carrier within that mode. (

) The PTP section is responsible for: a. Servicewide routing, pricing and procedures for IRS shipments b. Ensuring all personnel authorized to access the SPC system or TMS provided information on all shipments. c. Resolving all routing and pricing issues involving IRS shipments (
) The PTP section is directly involved in negotiations for SPC pricing and other service terms; the Department of Defense (D
) administers the negotiated pricing and service options. (
) Motor (truck) Freight rates, Air Freight rates and terms of service are negoti- ated directly with carriers and administered by the IRS. Rates, rules and service options are governed by Publication
, IRSTOS - Internal Revenue Service Tender of Service . The publication is available at: http://publish.no.irs.gov/cat
cgi?request=CAT
&itemtyp=P&itemb=
&items=*. (

) The PTP Section solicits individual carrier bids during the annual “open window” in August. Bid prices are entered into the TMS to facilitate carrier selection and cost estimates for creating IRBLs. These carriers must be used on IRS freight shipments when feasible. Transportation (

) Motor Freight - Shipment weight is the primary criteria used to determine mode of Motor Freight to use. On a per pound basis, the truckload mode is least expensive, less-than-truckload is more costly and SPC is the highest priced per pound. Transit time by Motor Freight is slower than by Air Freight. The weight ranges and corresponding modes are shown in the below table. Management
page
Two important steps in traffic management is negotiation of pricing and routing.

Mode Weight Ranges Truckload or TL Approximately 10,000 - 44,000 pounds or the weight (pricing point) at which it is more cost- effective to use TL pricing. This pricing point is identiﬁed as a weight break, and results in IRS paying a lower price per unit on a higher total weight for a net savings. Less-than-Truckload or LTL Over 750 pounds up to the TL weight break SPC (ground service) Up to 750 pounds per shipment or the weight break at which it is more cost-effective to use LTL pricing 1.22 Mail and Transportation Management
Note: Unless a work stoppage is identiﬁed by the recipient, 3-5 Day Deferred is preferred option.

) When shipping one piece weighing more than
pounds or a consolidated shipment with a combined weight over
pounds to one customer, shipping should be coordinated through the Employee Resource Center (ERC). ERC personnel can contact the PTP section for assistance.

Form 9814, Request for Mail/Shipping Services, must be completed for all air freight shipments over 13 ounces and less than 750 pounds. The form is available at: http://publish.no.irs.gov/cat12.cgi?request=CAT1&catnum=22023
) Freight shipments are a direct expense. Before shipping, a funded PPS request is required, unless the shipment is covered under IRM
, counting and Payment for Transportation, and funding is authorized by M&P. (

) Inside delivery/pickup is an additional service performed by freight carriers beyond the standard loading or unloading of the vehicle. Inside delivery/pickup costs extra but will only be done upon request when the carrier’s operating conditions permit. When requested on the IRBL or authorized at the time of delivery/pickup, the carrier can move shipments from or to positions beyond the normal loading or unloading area. (

) Because of the nature of freight carrier service and the independent control drivers have over their vehicles, problems emerge regarding inside delivery. Drivers may provide only a minimum level of service, sometimes less than their agreement with what IRS requires. Unfortunately, there is no guarantee the actual service performed will be the service expected. (

) Before inside delivery/pickup is arranged, determine which offices require services. Use the following criteria to determine inside delivery: a. If an office lacks administrative personnel to perform internal movement of shipments from or to the point immediately adjacent to the location the vehicle. b. If the loading or unloading facilities are not adequate for delivery/pickup without this service. (

) When inside delivery/pickup is requested and the driver delivering the shipment is unable to perform the service, follow these procedures: a. When the IRBL does not authorize inside delivery/pickup and the driver asks for payment, do not pay the driver. The receiver/shipper may authorize the service to be billed to the IRS by signing the driver’s documents. If that fails, call the PTP Section at

while the driver is there. The PTP employee will authorize payment of the inside/ pickup charges. b. When the IRBL authorizes the service, call the driver’s supervisor to determine why inside delivery/pickup service is being withheld. As a resort, call the PTP section at the number listed above. (
) Any problems or instances of carrier non-performance are to be documented by the delivery location and forwarded to the PTP section. (
) The PTP section is responsible for ensuring IRBLs for shipments are appropri- ately annotated. The PTP section will maintain and update a listing of the offices requiring inside delivery. (

) The Tax Forms Distribution Programs Section (TFDPS) is responsible for surveying offices requiring inside delivery and including information on the Internal Management Documents Distribution System address ﬁle. Those addresses become available to the PTP section through the TMS for creating IRBLs.

When the IRBL authorizes the service, call the driver’s supervisor to determine why inside delivery/pickup service is being withheld. As a last resort, call the PTP section at the number listed above.

1.22 Mail and Transportation Management
and Air Freight - Inside Delivery/Pickup (
) The delivery/pickup and unloading/loading of a shipment by the carrier includes the placing of a vehicle at the delivery/pickup site designated by the consignee/consignor. (
) The driver will unload/load at the delivery/pickup site immediately adjacent the delivery/pickup vehicle to/from a loading dock within
feet of the motor carrier’s tailgate or to/from a door or the area inside the door (within
feet the door). (

) Unloading/loading includes the counting and removing of the freight from the position in which it is transported in or on the carrier’s vehicle. The carrier is required to furnish only one person per vehicle. If additional carrier help is required, it must be pre-arranged before delivery/pickup is attempted. Addi- tional charges will be assessed for this service. (

) When receiving/sending a shipment, the IRS is responsible for the following: a. Unpacking/packing, dismantling or inspecting, sorting or segregating freight b. Furnishing equipment for palletized or containerized shipments c. Moving the freight to/from the loading dock or receiving/shipping area Note: IRS failure or unwillingness to provide these services often results in added costs because the carrier is authorized to bill extra fees to cover added services. (

) Restrictions on any carrier’s ability to provide inside delivery/pickup service usually due to the IRS building security and limited access restrictions. The mailroom is normally the delivery site for IRS locations. Damage - Discrepancies Claims (
) The consignee will inspect incoming shipments to determine whether any shown on the shipping document are missing or damaged. (

) Any visible damages, shortages or overages during the unloading of the shipment will be annotated by the consignee on the carrier’s delivery receipt and the copy of the IRBL. Note: It is critical for a successful claim to discover and note loss or damage at
Mail and Transportation Management
The consignee will inspect incoming shipments to determine whether any items shown on the shipping document are missing or damaged.

Note: It is critical for a successful claim to discover and note loss or damage at point of delivery. Both the consignee and the carrier’s driver must sign to ac- knowledge the notations. Discrepancies that appear to exceed $
should reported to the PTP section to ﬁle a claim for the IRS. (

) When a loss, damage or discrepancy is discovered after the delivery and the receipt of the shipment, the consignee is to promptly notify the nearest office the delivering carrier and request an inspection be performed. This is classiﬁed as “concealed loss or damage.” It is difficult to get full recovery in these cases. (
) The consignee is to make every effort to resolve overages or shortages within
working days after the detection by immediately notifying the delivering carrier. (

) When accessorial or special services, such as inside delivery, are authorized but have not been provided, the consignee must promptly notify the Territory Point of Contact or the PTP section so payment for the added charges is not approved.

) The carrier will provide forms for ﬁling of loss or damage claims, full disclosure is required detailing the extent of damage and criteria for the amount Include all supporting documents, a copy of the IRBL, delivery receipt, proof value, carrier’s inspection report and copies of correspondence with the concerning the loss or damage. Shipment (

) The carrier can trace a freight shipment when a reasonable time has been allowed for the shipment to reach its destination or to estimate the arrival For tracing both Motor and Air Freight shipments, the following information needs to be gathered before calling the carrier or initiating an online trace: • Pro number (freight bill) or air bill number • Pickup date and location • Number of pieces and weight • IRBL number • Services requested (e.g., Next Day, Guaranteed Delivery, etc.,) (

) To trace SPC shipments you must have the carrier tracking number. This enable you to trace the shipment online. Additional information at point of origin can be helpful such as: • Six-digit shipper or account number • Pickup date and address • Number of packages and the weight of each package • Consignee’s address • Type of service (
) All responses to a trace are to be printed or conﬁrmed by email. Payment (

) The IRS may not reduce carrier’s freight invoice amount because of loss and/or damage. Each proper invoice amount will be paid in full, and a formal claim will be ﬁled with the carrier for the amount of the loss or damage. If carrier does not make an adequate response within
days, this amount be deducted from a subsequent invoice. (
) The PTP section will not ﬁle a claim against a carrier for any loss or damage of less than $
Amounts below this amount will be absorbed by the ment. (
) Additional insurance coverage should not be purchased for IRS shipments. CFR

states the Government retains the risk of loss and damage to property that is not the legal liability of commercial carriers and does not insurance for its property in the possession of commercial carriers. This the IRS is self-insured. Depending on the mode of transportation used, insurance is provided as part of the transportation contract. For more tion contact the PTP section. Management

) Additional insurance coverage should not be purchased for IRS shipments.
CFR

states the Government retains the risk of loss and damage to its property that is not the legal liability of commercial carriers and does not buy insurance for its property in the possession of commercial carriers. This means the IRS is self-insured. Depending on the mode of transportation used, some insurance is provided as part of the transportation contract. For more informa- tion contact the PTP section.
